source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Transient-heating tube-burst tests were conducted on a $5 0 . 8 – c m$ length of Zircaloy cladding obtained from spent-fuel rods irradiated in the H. B. Robinson power reactor to a peak burn-up of $3 0 \mathrm { \ i M W D / k g }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Internal electrical resistance heaters were used to achieve nominal heating rates of $2 8 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C } / \mathsf { s }$ for the tests

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The tests were conducted in steam

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Tube burst pressures varied from 0.965 to $1 2 . 5 1 4 ~ \mathrm { { \bf ~ M P a } }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Corresponding burst stresses and temperatures varied from $7 . 5 \ \mathsf { M P a }$ and $1 1 3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ to ${ \mathfrak { s o } } _ { * 1 } { \ \mathbf { M } } { \bar { \mathbf { P } } } \mathbf { a }$ and $7 3 4 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Corresponding burst stresses and temperatures varied from $7 . 5 \ \mathsf { M P a }$ and $1 1 3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ to ${ \mathfrak { s o } } _ { * 1 } { \ \mathbf { M } } { \bar { \mathbf { P } } } \mathbf { a }$ and $7 3 4 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Failure strains ranged up to $4 6$ percent when burst occurred at upper $( \alpha +$ $\beta ,$ and $\beta$ -phase temperatures and up to 30 percent for failures occurring at lower temperatures

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Failure strains ranged up to $4 6$ percent when burst occurred at upper $( \alpha +$ $\beta ,$ and $\beta$ -phase temperatures and up to 30 percent for failures occurring at lower temperatures

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: No significant difference in burst behavior between unirradiated and spent nuclear fuel Zircaloy cladding was observed experimentally

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: No influence of axial restraint on burst strains was noted

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 tube specimens for this study were obtained from an assembly of spent-fuel rods irradiated in the Carolina Power and Light H. B. Robinson power reactor

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The fuel rods operated at peak powers in the range of 20 to $2 5 \mathrm { k W / m }$ to a peak burn-up of $3 0 \mathrm { M W D / k g }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: The fuel rods operated at peak powers in the range of 20 to $2 5 \mathrm { k W / m }$ to a peak burn-up of $3 0 \mathrm { M W D / k g }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: a corresponding peak fast-neutron fluence $\mathrm { ( > 1 ~ m e V ) }$ of $4 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 1 }$ $\mathbf { n } / \mathbf { c m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Postirradiation profilometry of the fuel rods revealed an average cladding creepdown of 75 to $1 0 0 \ \mu \mathbf { m }$ (3 to 4 mils)

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: maximum ovalities (difference between minimum and maximum cladding diameter) of 500 $\mu \mathbf { m }$ $( 2 0 \mathrm { \ m i l s } )$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk1
evidence_span: Outside surface oxide thicknesses ranged up to about $1 \ \mathrm { m i l }$ along the cladding length

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tube temperatures were measured by $1 2 7 - \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( 5 { \cdot } \mathrm { m i l } )$ chromel-alumel thermocouples spot welded to $7 6 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( 3 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { } \mathrm { } \mathrm { } \mathrm { m i l } )$ tantalum tabs that were in turn spot welded to the tube surface.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tube temperatures were measured by $1 2 7 - \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( 5 { \cdot } \mathrm { m i l } )$ chromel-alumel thermocouples spot welded to $7 6 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( 3 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { } \mathrm { } \mathrm { } \mathrm { m i l } )$ tantalum tabs that were in turn spot welded to the tube surface.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Thermocouple locations were selected by examination of infrared heater scans, obtained at about $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , to select probable failure locations based on maximum heater temperatures.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Maximum temperature variations measured at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ were typically $\pm 6 \mathrm { } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tests were conducted, with several exceptions, at a heating rate of $2 8 \pm 3 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } / \mathbf { s } .$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Pressures were measured to an accuracy of $\pm 0 . 1 4 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ .

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Tube deformation is seen to have occurred over the complete $3 8 . 1 ~ \mathrm { c m }$ of heater length.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Infrared heater scans, as seen in Fig. 2, indicated a rapid fall off in temperature over a length of about 6 cm at each end of the heater.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The application of axial restraint, up to the time of burst during transient heating, has no effect on the burst temperature.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: There is a slight tendency toward somewhat greater tube burst strains for tests conducted with axial restraint.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Failure in the alpha and through much of the $( \alpha + \beta )$ phase region occurred by development of a single neck that proceeded to failure.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: At higher temperatures, in the $\beta$ -phase region, multiple necks developed prior to failure.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: Measurements showed little difference between inside- and outside-oxide thickness or with angular position around the tubes.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk2
evidence_span: The inside oxide appeared to be slightly more porous than the outside oxide.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: the angular temperature difference in these tests appears to be of the order of 35 to $4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: Axial temperature differences account for data points that lie up to $9 5 \textdegree$ below the ORNL curve

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: (a) burst temperature $1 l 3 5 ^ { \circ } C .$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: (b) burst temperature $\ 8 I ^ { 4 } ^ { \circ } C$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: complete annealing of irradiation strengthening at temperatures below ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ during transient heating at rates up to $2 8 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } / \mathbf { s }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: Increases in ductility due to recrystallization tend to lag behind the strength changes but are beginning at ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ , even at the highest heating rate of $2 8 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } / \mathbf { s }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: unrestrained contractions up to $0 . 7 8 7 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ were permitted between grooves of the ratchet-and-pawl mechanism

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: the tensile properties were essentially independent of maximum cladding temperature and cooling rate, but were dependent on the oxygen distribution through the cladding wall

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk3
evidence_span: "the oxygen concentration must be less than 0.7 weight percent over at least half the cladding thickness."

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_032_chunk4
evidence_span: Under the conditions postulated for a loss-of-coolant accident (LOCA) the Zircaloy-4 fuel cladding of the CANDU (CANada-Deuterium-Uranium) reactor may experience a temperature transient during which it absorbs an appreciable quantity of oxygen.
